First off, I want you all to know that after nearly 20 years of PC gaming, this is the 3rd review i'm posting about a game ever. Why? Because I think this game deserves some credit, and half the reviews here are complete BS or either people don't know what to expect from early-acces games. I'm about 40 hours in and can tell you this:

1. PRICE 
This is an Early-Acces game, in it's very early stages with a small dev team. Keeping that in mind, the game is already looking really good, and people shouldn't expect a game this large for all functions to work smoothly yet. €17 is a damn fair starting price. They don't charge you €20/30+ for a very EA-game and keep the price correct and acceptable. If you like survival/building/crafting games, i advise to get it now before the price goes up!

2. DEV-TEAM
On that same note, this dev team is working day and night and is dropping patches nearly every week, sometimes even two a week. There is an active discord community, where the devs read all our bug-reports and if necessary respond to our trouble-shooting.

3. GAME-MODES/OPTIONS
This game supports all kinds of play (PvE, PvP and RP). I have to say it's leaning more towards the RP part with PvE and PvP functions. So know what you are getting in to and don't expect an all-out western brawl shooting game and then give it a bad review because the PvP sucks. You need to build, farm, maintain, support and most of all, grind. Yes your horses and livestock can die if you don't log on every 2 days, so lasso a new horse, get new life-stock, it doesn't take long! The map is huge with different environments and all kinds of wildlife, with bandits and outlaw gangs roaming free. There are no set PvE buildings or NPC's, however you can build several for your town if you like. You can make party's and guilds.

4. SERVERS
As this is EA and certain updates/patches can have a serious impact on the environment, you have to expect map wipes on official servers every so often. (this is no different from other survival-building games f.e. H1Z1, 7D2D, Rust, Miscreated, Ark, ....) If you can't handle that, run your own private server and narrow that down to a minimum. There are plenty of servers for many different regions which is a plus. On the downside there are some connection issues on the official servers as i've heard. I'm however on a private RP server not experiencing this.

5. FUTURE 
I think a lot of people, myself included, have been waiting for a fun western themed game to come out. And I can tell you this, with work and fine-tuning and people playing the game, this one could become a very popular MMORPG, western style in the survival/building genre. However knowing the stage it is in, you should accept that this is for a lot of people not the game to play non-stop yet. Play once in a while, have some fun and wait for improvements to drop (keep a cool head and know to expect bugs and glitches for at least the next year or 2).

I could list you all the things you can do and build already, the pro's and con's, but nothing tells it better than a video. The game is already being captured and streamed enough, so i'd say go watch a video. If you like grinding, building, customizing, and most of all, just have good laughs with friends being silly in a game... Building your own towns in great detail with this amazing crafting system, I do recommend adding this one to your librabry.

If you expect a graphically perfect game with loads of PvP-shoutouts, go play RDR2, or a fun shooter like Fistful of Frags. If you like a realistic game, perfect for RP then this is the one!

This game should be a lot more fun than it actually is. At first glance, surviving in the late 1800's American west sounded like a lot of fun. I had visions of riding from mining camp to native village to frontier outpost until I found some perfect spot to build a base of my own, perhaps even a town. My optimism was not to be rewarded.

Just to start, it takes far longer than it should to get into the game itself. Even loading a single player server takes way too long. On my decent computer it never takes less than 5 - 7 minutes. It's also unnecessarily annoying. There is a purposeful, very bad blurring of a loading screen that has things moving on it. My eyes declare vendetta on the rest of me if I don't look away from the screen while the game loads. When that loading screen goes away it's replaced by a series of still, in game shots in which game characters stare at you with soulless, dead eyes. There aren't enough letters in the word creepy to describe just how creepy it is.

Character creation is bland, boring and ugly. There is nothing to differentiate it from character creation in games a decade older. I'm pretty sure Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion had more and better options than this game does.

Your character wakes up in a coffin. You break out before you have any control of your character. That's pretty cool to see. It explains why your character is out in the middle of nowhere: Someone left you here, either thinking you were dead, or intending for you to be dead shortly. After all, you're left in nothing but a union suit (the one-piece long underwear with a flap in the back) with no supplies whatsoever.

Everything goes downhill from there. Open up your crafting menu, I dare you. Yes, you can create most anything in the game already. At most, you're only one menu away from creating it. Much of what you can initially make are crafting benches or tools that open up more crafting options. Make a mallet and you can build basic wooden house pieces. All of them. No learning system, no customization, no receiving new items to build as you progress. Nope, the game developers simply dump everything on you all at once. It's about as fun as you think reading the descriptions of dozens of items trying to figure out what you need to make first in a game that has no pause option. That's right, even hitting escape to bring up your menu doesn't pause the game. I hope you never intend to go AFK because your character will get hungry, thirsty, and die if you're gone too long. Even in single player.

Exploring is next to pointless. There was a decent place to build a single house within sight of where I spawned in. When I died, prior to having a bed to respawn in, the game always started me back in that same spot so I'm not sure if there even are any other respawn points in the game.

When I did start exploring it was only after I'd built a mailbox at my house. I hadn't realized it was actually useful in single player. I'd assumed it was just for sending in game messages to players who weren't online. Nope, there are contracts. You can hire various npcs and some prefabricated buildings through it. Which meant I could, theoretically, construct a town.

So I moved my house to somewhere that sorta resembled flat land, built a larger house and then realized I needed money. A game set in the American west is going to use dollars, of course. But how to make money? Well, you can sell things to npcs...except you have to buy the npcs first. But there must be a way to make money initially, right? There is. Sort of.

Bandits. They can be in groups of up to 4 and range in difficulty between the sort of bandits you see in comedic westerns up to four man gangs that seem to be comprised of strafe-happy aimbots. Kill bandits, get money. Slowly.

And that's assuming you can kill the bandits. Once you build the appropriate crafting table you can build every gun in the game. Or at least you can build about twenty different guns. I suppose it's possible that others exist. Build yourself whichever guns seem best and go bandit hunting.

Just don't try to zoom in to aim better, you lose your already terrible aiming reticle and movement becomes a stuttering nightmare. Maybe my graphics card is too weak, but game graphics aren't impressive so I find that explanation less than satisfactory.

And the game is now over. Sure, you can kill bandits by the score until you have enough money to buy an npc to sell things to. Then you can buy more npcs and prefabricated buildings. But why? More than any other survival game I've played thus far, and the single biggest failing of Outlaws is the complete lack of any answer to the question "why?"

Why explore? Why build? Why hunt animals or bandits? Why should I care about the fate of my character? Outlaws has no answer for any of the questions that make survival games enjoyable.

This is the first survival game I've played where I could realistically build a house exactly where I spawned in and collect almost every resource in the game without leaving sight of that building. And yet I'm left without any particular motivation to do that.

Maybe Outlaws will improve. I'm hoping it does. But purchasing the game in its current form would be a mistake. I bought it when it was on sale and even that small quantity of money feels wasted. I'll likely keep trying to find a purpose in this game because I have spent money on it. Don't make my mistake. Keep this game on your wishlist in the hopes that one day this digital Old West will be fun. As it stands, Louis and Clark would have turned around and headed back east after a few hours had this been the land they were exploring.

Things I love:
Horses are build correctly. This is my number one pet peeve in a game. Artists who never even bother to learn basic four legged mammal anatomy and yet try to create things like horses. Horses actually look like horses. They have Mustangs and Quarter Horses atm, and they are discernibly different, to a horse person.

The ability for one person, playing alone on a server to have an impact and build a whole town on their own. Though I am sure this would be different on a pvp heavy server.

The growing repertoire of items that we can build. I hope this keeps growing. There is so much amazing potential in this game. I'd hate for the developers to do what many other survival games have done and give up part way through.

Did I mention the horses?

Things I don't like:
Graphical bugs. Rarely life threatening, but can be annoying and make it hard for immersion in such an otherwise beautiful game. Example, hair sticking out through the hat. Items not always sitting on the ground, etc... simple stuff that will likely get patched in the future.

Lack of easy method to reporting bugs to devs. There doesn't' seem to be any communication, that I have found, between developers and the community. When I run across bugs, I'd love to be able to report them, but that is not a viable option in game. Nor have I found a reliable place to do so outside of the game.

Lack of other tameable animals such as dogs, cows, goats. The latter of the two exist in the wild, but unlike the horses, there is no way to tame them. Or at the very least run them into a paddock where I can farm them for meat and hide later.

Lack of breeding. Such as for horses or the above mentioned cattle and goat herd, if we could have them.

The reliance on seeds from NPC's to farm and cook recipe meals. There should be more than fruits and berries found in the wild.

Bandits that can slide sideways across the ground as if they were flying. I can't move that fast sideways, they shouldn't be able to either.

Well that isn't a full list, but it should be enough for you to get the basic idea of the state of the game. It is in development. the Devs are still adding and making regular fixes and changes. So there is TONS of possibility with this game, and I look forward to spending many hours on it. Oh, and I have played, Ark, Atlas, Conan Exiles and such. So I do have some experience with these types of games.
